# **Main references: Weak convergence**

1. [Convergence of Probability measures](http://search.lib.unc.edu/search?R=UNCb2554346). Large parts of the course follow the 1968 book but we cover an assorted collection of special topics and examples. 

2. [Durret's Probability Theory and examples](https://services.math.duke.edu/~rtd/PTE/PTEv5a.pdf)
Fantastic treatment of the Martingale FCLT in Chapter 8. 

# **Main references: Local weak convergence**

1. [Aldous and Steele's survey on the Objective method.](https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~aldous/Papers/me101.pdf) Beautiful survey of the applications of the method in probabilistic combinatorial optimization by two masters in the field. 

2. [Benjamini and Schramm's work on distribution limits of Planar graphs.](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ejp/1461097653)

3. [Dembo and Montanari's work on Gibbs measures on sparse random graphs](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bjps/1271770268). Also see their [Annals of  Probability paper.](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aoap/1268143433)

4. [Side reading: Chapter 8 of Bishop's pattern recognition and machine learning](http://www.springer.com/us/book/9780387310732). Gives a nice overview of probabilistic graphical models. In particular Section 4 on message passing algorithms and their role in computing marginal distributions in the context of Markov random fields especially when the graphical structure is tree like was a fun read. 

5. [Montanari's St. Flour lecture notes](https://www.dropbox.com/s/u7ewrjpcktrp3db/stflour-montannari_2.pdf?dl=0). Gives a number of complete proofs and a concise overview of the field.

<a name="lwc-fur">
 **Further reading on local weak convergence**
</a>

See the main references for applications in settings like Factor models and machine learning. For more specialized applications:

- [**Asymptotic Fringe convergence of random trees (Aldous)**](http://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/2959767.pdf?refreqid=excelsior%3Adab502dd000b5d875724574041cdf929). One of the earliest papers on local weak convergence especially developed for trees. A classic!

- [**Graphical models and compressed sensing (Montanari):**](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1011.4328) Surveys how message passing algorithms can be used to understand fundamental objects like the LASSO. See [Donoho,Malekib and Montanari](http://www.pnas.org/content/106/45/18914.abstract) for a more technical description of the contributions. One line blurb from the abstract: "*We introduce a simple costless modification to iterative thresholding making the sparsity–undersampling tradeoff of the new algorithms equivalent to that of the corresponding convex optimization procedures. The new iterative-thresholding algorithms are inspired by belief propagation in graphical models. Our empirical measurements of the sparsity–undersampling tradeoff for the new algorithms agree with theoretical calculations. We show that a state evolution formalism correctly derives the true sparsity–undersampling tradeoff.* "

- **Random matrix theory**: See [Bordenave and Lelarge](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/rsa.20313/full); [Bhamidi, Evans, Sen](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10959-011-0360-9); See the following [survey by Bordenave and Chafai](http://emis.ams.org/journals/PS/images/getdocd7e0.pdf?id=772&article=183&mode=pdf) for a beautiful description of the state of the art and many more references. 

- **Random Schrodinger operators**: See [Aizenmann and Warzel](https://arxiv.org/abs/math-ph/0607021) for rigorous results relating these problems to the "canopy" tree. 

- [**Strategic learning on networks: Mossel, Sly and Tamuz**](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.3982/ECTA12058/full)

- [**Large deviations for graphs: Bordenave and Caputo**](http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00440-014-0590-8)

- **Applications of such ideas in optimization**: Here the number of applications are infinite! Just as a starting point, see for example 

    - [Maximum weight independent sets and matchings in sparse random graphs. Exact results using the local weak convergence method](http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/rsa.20072/full)
    - [Max-Product for Maximum Weight Matching: Convergence, Correctness, and LP Duality by Bayati, Shah
and Sharma](http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/4455730/).
    - Also see [Belief Propagation for Min-Cost Network Flow: Convergence and Correctness](http://pubsonline.informs.org/doi/abs/10.1287/opre.1110.1025)
    
- **Community detection**: See [Asymptotic analysis of the stochastic block model for modular networks and its algorithmic applications](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1109.3041.pdf) and the multitude of papers that cite this for understanding how accurate the predictions of such methodology are for predicting "reconstruction limits" of models. See the work of [Mossel, Neeman and Sly](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v35/mossel14.pdf) for a complete rigorous justification of these predictions.

- Another wonderful treatment: [Steve Evans St. Flour lecture notes](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007%2F978-3-540-74798-7)

- The following are the original Aldous classics: [CRT 1](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aop/1176990534), [CRT 2](https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~aldous/Papers/me55.pdf) and [CRT 3](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aop/1176989404).

 **Skorohod topology**
</a>

I still do not have great intuition for this space. In addition to the Chapter in Billingsley's book, other places with good treatments of the fundamentals include:

- [Chapter 3 of Ward Whitt's book on Stochastic processes limits](http://www.springer.com/us/book/9780387953588)

- [Chapter 6 of Jacod and Shiryaev's book on Limit Theorems for Stochastic Processes](http://www.springer.com/us/book/9783540439325)

- [Chapter 3 of Ethier and Kurtz's book on Markov processes](http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-047176986X.html)
